ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: If students have some knowledge of conservation already, they may find, as I did, that this course gives a broad overview of conservation around the world. I would have appreciated some more specificity in case studies, in lectures, even in the final assignments, in order to push us to learn new concepts.
This is one of the few classes that focuses on practical conservation skills - the availability of this course is invaluable for FES students!

Excellent course, and one of the few that is truly about conservation. Wish FES had more courses on this topic. Thanks Amy & Bill for continuing to offer this as an opportunity for FES students of conservation. A really unique class where you learn from the experts!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The breadth of the course, quality of discussion, and professor's personal insight were valuable aspects of this course.

There aren't very many conservation oriented classes at Yale, and so I think having Amy and Bill's course is extremely valuable. They did a great job of incorporating a range of backgrounds and creating a space in which students could learn form their experience as well as each other's.

I really really enjoyed the guest speakers. Talking to them was the most valuable part of the course. Meeting professionals in the field, networking, sharing a meal with them: all of this was supremely beneficial to getting international perspectives on conservation.
Rapid Fire Discussions Learning about Bill and Amy's experiences
The use of case studies on complex conservation issues.

Student-led discussions were always interesting. Being the lead on a particular topic resulting in the greatest learning as it required you to become somewhat of an expert on the topic. I also really enjoyed the final paper and appreciated that it was an open topic.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Perhaps the professors should consider covering the more complex course topics ordinarily left for student-led presentations. At times, students were not able to cover topics in depth because of time constraints.

The class tried to cover a lot of material in a short amount of time, and sometimes it felt like we were having the same discussions in multiple contexts. I think it would be helpful to make sure that we're not repeating ourselves in order to cover more material.

Many of the themes are simply too broad to be taught in one lecture. It would be helpful if readings and discussions were very place-based. For instance, have a lecture on payments for ecosystem services with readings focused on this type of program in Colombia. That way, people can understand how the tool plays out on the ground. As it stands now, the themes are too broad to really take away valuable learning points.
Too broad of class discussions Student-led classes often overlapped too much

I think the course could be significantly improved through the utilization of a single (or few) case studies that consistently run through the semester, through which we could look at the individual topics. I think there could also be improvement in how we discuss the "big questions" - I often felt the conversation stayed "big," making it hard to contribute or to move forward with any tangible solutions. Better professor guidance on some of these topics would help.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, discussions were very valuable because they allowed us to flesh out ideas introduced in lecture and to ask more probing questions.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided practical conservation knowledge, primarily in an international context, which contributed to my interest in international conservation policy and governance.
I hope to pursue further studies in conservation, and this course felt like a great introduction to help me better understand what topics I want to pursue further.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to learn more about how to actually "do conservation" and which questions are the most important ones to ask regarding international conservation.
I took this course because there are very few other conservation oriented courses, and this one looked like it covered an important range of topics without requiring previous experience.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! The discussions we had in class and topics we covered have prompted me to ask more insightful questions.
Yes - I feel like I now have a basic understanding of a lot of conservation topics.

I think I expected to learn new things about conservation internationally, but I feel I learned about broad concepts I already knew about, but with an overview of how these tools play out across the world. The concepts weren't new, but the examples were.

Yes and no. I appreciated the opportunity to discuss complicated conservation issues - but I sometimes felt that I left class exactly where I started, partly because these questions must be discussed in the context of a specific project.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I appreciated learning about my partners perspectives on our presentation topic. Through assembling the power point and compiling the readings, we were able to prioritize topics we found most interesting or important.

The main disadvantage of doing the group class leading was that didn't feel that the class benefitted very much from our lecture. I felt like the process of putting together a lecture was fun, but overall, what we taught was surface-level, and not very interesting. I think hearing more from Bill and Amy about examples they think are important to discuss from around the world would be more valuable.
Advantages were getting to know my classmates; disadvantages were the usual: coordination.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Create a list of questions you have about conservation and be prepared to discuss them! Amy and Bill love talking about different perspectives and complicated topics.

Definitely take it! Amy and Bill are wonderful, and very experienced in the field. The interdisciplinary approach is really interesting, and it's also helpful to hear the case studies presented by fellow students. You also get to meet and make connections with really cool guest speakers!

Bill and Amy are awesome and it's worth taking the course just to get to know them. However, sometimes it felt like they had a particular point of view and were less responsive to exploring others. The class can feel scattered and too broad, but still has a lot of merit if you're interested in conservation work.
